The combination of left-sided pyramidal weakness with spasticity and hyperreflexia (most marked in the leg), left hemisensory loss, right upper-limb limb ataxia with dysdiadochokinesia, gait ataxia, downbeat nystagmus, and a partial Horner’s syndrome is best explained by a single lesion at the right cervicomedullary junction/posterior fossa compressing the pre-decussation corticospinal tracts, sensory pathways, cerebellar connections, vestibular structures, and descending sympathetic fibres.
